**Chapter 61: On the *Dao/Way* of the Great Realm (大国者下流)**

True Statement says: This chapter emphatically declares that the sage-ruler always cherishes humility as his *virtue/power*. How could he seek victory or defeat through arms and raw force?

In the exchanges between great and small realms, the principle of fostering mutual relations and interests must be upheld. Examining their logic, does it not simply mean each pursues what it desires?

If each seeks what it desires, then the great must naturally assume a posture of humility and clarity. The *Dao/Way* of humility and modesty always diminishes the high to elevate the low; its efficacy lies with the ruler, not the ruled. Therefore, the *Classic of Changes* says: *"By honoring the lowly and disdaining the noble, one gains the people."* This is what it means.

---

**Chapter 62: On the *Dao/Way* as the *Source of All Things* (道者万物)**

True Statement says: The sage-ruler treasures this *Dao/Way* because it can safeguard and nurture the people of the world. Among the people of the world, the virtuous are few, while the unvirtuous are many—could he abandon them all?

Thus, the sage-ruler establishes governance, appoints the Three Ministers, strives to restrain arms and warfare, avoids punishments, beautifies speech, and honors conduct, hoping to guide them toward goodness and transform them through principle. Therefore, he is held in esteem by all under heaven.

Why would he bow to jade and horses and seek to compare their superiority? This is the *Dao/Way* of non-action (为无为).

---

**Chapter 63: On the *Dao/Way* of Non-Action (至道之君)**

True Statement says: The ruler who embodies the ultimate *Dao/Way* sits upright and lets governance unfold naturally, hence it is called the *Dao/Way* of non-action (为无为). He lays down arms and avoids contention, hence it is called the *Dao/Way* of treating non-action as action (事无事). He embodies the *Dao/Way* and preserves the spirit, hence it is called the *Dao/Way* of savoring non-savor (味无味).

The hearts of all realms and the nature of myriad people—like winter’s cold and summer’s rain—still evoke sighs of complaint. Yet the ruler’s heart, whether great or small, few or many, must always be guided by *virtue/power* to soothe them, ensuring no resentment or blame arises. Therefore, it is said: *"Repay resentment with virtue."* (报怨以德)

The world’s great difficulties always arise from what is easy, meaning that if a ruler acts with negligence or ease, then calamities will surely emerge from it.

The world’s great undertakings always arise from what is slight, meaning that if a ruler does not value small actions, his great *virtue/power* will ultimately be undermined. Thus, the sage-ruler prevents minor issues from escalating and accumulates small deeds to achieve greatness. If one waits until a matter is already settled or fully grown before acting, it will be too late. Therefore, it is said: *"Only by never treating greatness as great can one achieve true greatness."* (终不为大，乃能成其大)

If one lightly gives promises, trust will be few; if one frequently alters course, difficulties will multiply—this is the natural order of things.

The *Dao/Way* of simplicity is easy to follow, while the folly of negligence breeds difficulty. Thus, the sage-ruler treats even the most difficult matters with utmost caution, and only then can he master all affairs and all schemes without encountering difficulty. Therefore, it is said: *"Only by never treating difficulty as difficult can one overcome it."* (终无难)

---

**Chapter 64: On the *Dao/Way* of Ease and Holding Firm (易持易谋)**

True Statement says: This chapter fully speaks of success and failure resting with humanity, of the *Dao/Way* governing beginning and end, and of why the sage-ruler does not recklessly act to seek quick results. Thus, he dwells in security while contemplating danger, hence it is said: *"Ease in holding firm."* (易持)

He does not defy the natural order of things, hence it is said: *"Ease in planning."* (易谋)

If suddenly there are wicked schemes causing trouble, one must strike at their vulnerable beginnings—breaking them will be easy. If one intercepts their subtle origins, dispersing them will be without difficulty. Therefore, it is said: *"Act before there is a matter to act upon, and govern before there is disorder."* (为之於未有，理之於未乱) This refers to the sage’s foresight and early awareness before things have sprouted or taken form, desiring to act early and fearing their growth into unmanageable difficulties.

Again, great trees grow from fine shoots, high towers rise from small mounds, and long journeys begin with near steps—these three illustrate how small things accumulate to become great, and how near things lead to the distant. If one waits at the edge, hoping for results, then the time of fulfillment will surely come. But if one exceeds proper measure and seeks results prematurely, it will be the burden of hasty desires. Therefore, military campaigns cannot be forced; those who force them will surely bring ruin upon themselves. Weapons cannot be seized; those who seize them will surely lose them. Thus, the sage-ruler does nothing and grasps nothing, so he cannot be ruined or lose—this is clear.

Moreover, common folk always act with excessive doubt, preferring detours when on the path. In waging war or defending the realm, they often bring ruin upon themselves just as victory is in sight. These are all cases of losing sight of the fundamentals and confusing the beginning and end.

Therefore, it is said: *"Be as cautious at the end as at the beginning, and there will be no failed matters."* (慎终如始，则无败事)

Thus, the sage-ruler desires what others do not desire, hence it is said: *"He does not prize hard-to-obtain treasures."* (不贵难得之货) He learns what others do not learn, hence it is said: *"He corrects the errors of the multitude."* (复众人之所过) He seeks to assist all things in their natural unfolding, allowing them to mature effortlessly, and never dares to monopolize or claim exclusive insight, saying: *"He aids the natural unfolding of all things, yet does not dare to act."* (以辅万物之自然，而不敢为)

---

**Chapter 65: On the Ancient Rulers’ Skill in the *Dao/Way* (古之善为道)**

True Statement says: This speaks of the ancient rulers who skillfully embodied the *Dao/Way*. They did not teach the people to have cunning, for cunning hides deceit, nor did they teach them to be straightforward, for straightforwardness lies in their nature. Therefore, it is said: *"The people are difficult to govern because their cunning is excessive."* (人之难治，以其智多)

Again, it is said: *"To govern the realm with cunning is to be the realm’s thief."* (以智治国，国之贼)

What does this mean? The common folk are inherently of shallow and inferior nature, their wisdom and insight undeveloped, while deceit and scheming run rampant, stirring resentment and complaints. How could they discern right from wrong, or know what is proper and what is not? Some swarm like ants in their local cliques, others rise like bees across rivers and mountains. A single wicked instigator plots, and ten thousand follow in chorus. Military campaigns are always launched from such origins.

This does not mean that using cunning to govern the realm is itself the realm’s thief—rather, it means that if the common folk are made cunning, then all will become capable of harming the realm. Thus, to make the people of the world retain their natural simplicity and straightforwardness is to bring true fortune and blessing to the realm.

If the ruler of a realm can always understand these two principles, then he himself becomes the model and standard for all, which is called *"harmonizing with the *virtue/power* of Heaven."* (与天同德)

His profound and distant *virtue/power* is such that if rulers follow and emulate him, all things under heaven will naturally return to their original simplicity. Then the people of the world will surely attain great harmony. Therefore, it is said: *"Only then can great harmony be achieved."* (然后乃至大顺)

---

**Chapter 66: On the River and Sea as the Sovereign of All Valleys (江海所以能为百谷王)**

True Statement says: This chapter uses the river and sea as an analogy, desiring that the ruler embody the utmost humility, gentleness, and yielding.

The utmost humility, gentleness, and yielding earn the world’s affection. Earning the world’s affection brings boundless joy that does not weary, and boundless joy that does not weary ensures that none under heaven will contend. The principle of non-contention aligns with the *virtue/power* of Heaven, benefiting all things, and does not rely on forced compliance. It flows through the six voids without seeking to dominate, and does not plot to conquer. Moreover, who among the people of the world could contend with one who does not contend? It is impossible.

**Chapter 67: On the Greatness of the Three Treasures (天下皆謂我大)**

True Statement says: This chapter seeks to clarify the essence of the Three Treasures, first illustrating the *Greatness* through its text. The *Greatness* is the manifestation of the Dao/Way, though the common folk do not recognize it, hence they say it resembles the unworthy. This is to urge the ruler to deeply examine the meaning of the Three Treasures, safeguard and uphold them, so first it opens with the principle of giving and taking, to reveal the *virtue/power* of benevolence and frugality. Benevolence makes one courageous, meaning that with one’s own benevolent heart, one gains the world’s loyal devotion—what else could this be but courage? Frugality makes one expansive, meaning that with one’s own frugality and restraint, one attains the world’s wealth—what else could this be but abundance?

Thus, the Three Sovereigns employed it and overcame the Nine Li, the Five Emperors employed it and banished the Four Evildoers, Shang Tang and Wu employed it and conquered the world with arms, and Cheng, Kang, Wen, and Jing employed it so that punishments were all laid aside.

When Jié and Zhòu abandoned it, their states perished; when Yōu and Lǐ abandoned it, they met their deaths. When Qin Shǐ abandoned it, the Two Dynasties were exterminated; when Xiàng Jí abandoned it, his five limbs were severed. When Han Wǔ abandoned it, half the world was in ruin; when Cáo Pōng abandoned it, Wu and Shu stood in opposition. Hence it is said: "Abandon benevolence and lose courage; abandon frugality and lose abundance."

When it says "abandon benevolence," it means to discard love and care for the people, so that they offer no loyal devotion in return. Then, with one’s own daring spirit, one seeks to rival the world’s enmity—how could such boldness ever succeed?

When it says "abandon frugality," it means to lack restraint, to hoard wealth excessively, to indulge in palaces and luxuries, to increase armies and expenditures. When grain and resources are depleted, who can the ruler rely on? Moreover, the Classics say: "Follow your own body and yet lead others," and "To lead others, one must first place oneself behind them." Therefore, the sage never dares to act first for the world, yet ultimately always leads the world.

Thus, the effects of employing benevolence from the Yellow Emperor down to Wen and Jing were as described, and the consequences of abandoning it from Jié and Zhòu down to Cáo Pōng were as seen. Hence it is said: "With benevolence in war, one triumphs; with benevolence in defense, one is secure. When Heaven intends to save, it shields with benevolence." The good warrior does not revel in victory (善为士者不武).

True Statement says: The ruler who embodies the Dao/Way always engages in non-action, practices teaching without words—what need is there for martial prowess? The skilled warrior never suffers defeat, for they must prioritize tranquility and simplicity above all. Though it says "triumph," the sage does not take pride, instead treating it with sorrow, grief, and funeral rites—what room is there for anger?

The virtuous ruler’s *virtue/power* aligns with Heaven and Earth, naturally free from contention. Hence it is said: "The good victor does not contend." The king who regulates expenditures and loves the people, who governs with timely measures, must rely on ministers of assistance—these are compared to limbs and sinews. When employing generals, they kneel to receive the axe, march to advance the chariot—this is to first win their hearts, then their strength.

Hence it is said: "The good user of people acts beneath them," which is the *virtue/power* of non-contention. The *virtue/power* of non-contention can match Heaven and establish the ultimate principle—hence it is called the "Ancient Principle."

**Chapter 68: On the Words of Military Strategy (用兵有言)**

True Statement says: The ruler who follows the Dao/Way cannot speak for themselves, so they borrow the words of military strategy. In war, the one who strikes first is the host, the one who responds is the guest. Moreover, the sage’s use of arms is always as a last resort, so they act only after the enemy does. By acting only after the enemy, they are always the guest.

Advancing little and retreating often is the art of deep strategy, the intention of weighing the enemy carefully. Thus, though enemies may come, we rely on skilled tactics rather than battle formations. When we rely on skilled tactics rather than battle formations, there is no need for conquest—hence it is said: "Action without action." Since there is no need for conquest, our troops embrace righteousness in defense—what need is there for flexing muscles?

The ruler who follows the Dao/Way, even if faced with violent marauders who act recklessly, will first warn them with words, then display martial displays with banners and flags. The enemy will surely retreat upon hearing righteousness, naturally leaving no foe behind—hence it is said: "Yet there is no enemy." Once the enemy retreats, weapons are stored away—hence it is said: "Hold without arms." Though arms are stored away, fearing they may forget war, it is again warned: "No greater calamity than treating the enemy lightly; treating the enemy lightly nearly loses our treasure."

To treat the enemy lightly means to delight in foreign wars while neglecting domestic defenses. Better to delight in foreign wars than neglect domestic defenses, for even in foreign wars there may be victory or defeat, but neglecting domestic defenses will surely lead to annihilation.

Hence the lament: "Few know me, those who follow me are honored."

*Honored* is also like *few*. Since people cannot recognize and follow my teachings, this is why the Way and virtue cannot be put into practice. Because the Way and virtue cannot be put into practice, the Sage remains hidden in obscurity while storing brilliance within, adhering to the principle of "dwelling without emerging." Hence it is said: "Clad in coarse garments, yet holding jade within." (See Chapter 71 for the explanation of *knowing the unknown*.)

My true words are: One who knows what they know yet does not speak of it is superior among men. Conversely, one who does not know what they know yet insists on speaking of it is afflicted with a malady. Thus, recognizing this false knowledge as a disease means one will not fall ill. As for the critical moment in warfare, only the Sage and the Virtuous can truly grasp it. (See Chapter 72 for *The people do not fear authority*.)

My true words are: Great authority is the strength of arms and soldiers. If commoners have no fear, then punishments and penalties will follow; if ministers have no fear, then disgrace and humiliation will follow; if lords have no fear, then arms and soldiers will follow. Again, the scriptures say: "Do not fear what others fear," which carries the same meaning. Moreover, I warn those in high positions: They should cultivate a broad and magnanimous heart, lest their nature become narrow and constricted. They must not despise the natural purpose of their own lives. For if they do not despise their own existence, they will surely value governing others. If they value governing others, the people will gladly submit. Once the people submit willingly, who could possibly resent them? Thus, the ruler must first establish what cannot be resented, and only then can they ensure the people do not resent them. Hence it is said: "Only the one who does not resent can ensure no resentment."

The Sage’s wisdom inherently knows itself—how could they willingly boast of their own talents and display them for others to see? The Sage’s benevolence inherently practices self-love—how could they arrogantly dominate others and exploit things to achieve their own exalted status? Therefore, they abandon the great delusion of self-promotion and self-exaltation, and embrace the vast benefit of self-knowledge and self-love. Hence it is said: "Abandon that, take this."

(See Chapter 73 for *The daring and the reckless lead to slaughter*.)

My true words are: If a ruler is bold yet also fierce and reckless, they will inevitably love warfare and seek to dominate the world, thereby slaughtering many. If a ruler is bold yet not fierce or reckless, they will surely focus on the Dao and govern their realm, thereby preserving the lives of many. Hence it is said: "Knowing these two paths, one brings benefit, the other harm."

Those whom Heaven detests are those who love slaughter. The Sage has long known this. Now I again say that even those who struggle to grasp it should be warned severely. The Sage follows Heaven’s Way and practices the Dao, establishing deeds without action and teaching without words. In the world, who would dare to contend with them? Since there is none to contend with, how could they ever fail to triumph? Hence it is said: "The non-contending will excel in victory."

Heaven responds to human desires swiftly, like the echo of a sound. Cold comes with the summer solstice, heat with the winter solstice—this is not by chance. All things flow in their forms, each fulfilling its nature and destiny—this is not by mere coincidence. The vast and encompassing net of Heaven, the ruler should emulate its laws: Overlook great faults, unless they are truly negligent. Punish even small offenses, unless they are truly without blame. Again, the *Book of Documents* says: "When Heaven inflicts calamity, it can still be averted; but when a man brings calamity upon himself, it cannot be escaped," which carries the same meaning.

(See Chapter 74 for *The people do not fear death*.)

My true words are: When warfare is relentless and punishments are severe, the people will have no refuge. Once the people have no refuge, they will not fear death—this is clear. If they do not fear death, how can they still be held accountable for crimes? The people will escape without shame, and this is their downfall. If the ruler governs through virtue and the Way, the people will cherish life and fear death, naturally harboring shame and restraint. Once they have shame and restraint, if there are still wicked and evil individuals who dare to act strangely and deceptively, then I will seize and execute them. These are the soldiers who create confusion and deceive the masses through their strange and cunning tactics. Yet even so, since they are what Heaven detests, I still cannot act arbitrarily. Hence it is said: "Who dares?"

There are always officials entrusted with execution, and these officials are the agents of Heaven’s net. Moreover, the ruler of all under Heaven must take personal responsibility for crimes committed in every direction, awaiting Heaven’s divine retribution to act. How could they instead vent their emotions and shift their anger, indiscriminately punishing the innocent? Hence it is said: "Even the great carpenter, if they replace another in their work, will rarely avoid injury to their own hands."

(See Chapter 75 for *The people’s hunger*.)

My true words are: When a ruler imposes heavy labor, excessive taxation, and burdensome levies, famine will inevitably arise—this is natural. Again, it is said that those who act will be the rulers who love warfare and military campaigns. If one household has soldiers, then the entire clan will have soldiers; if one clan has soldiers, then the entire village will have soldiers; if one village has soldiers, then the entire realm will have soldiers; if the entire realm has soldiers, chaos will have no end. Then the farmer abandons their tools to wield weapons, the artisan discards their loom to rest in idleness, and in the state of Qi, half the households are of soldiers. Sons, brothers, neighbors, and kinsmen all join the ranks of warriors, together committing atrocities and deceit. Even if they are skillful in persuasion and gentle in manner, who could say it is easy? Hence it is said: "Difficult to govern."

As for those who lightly regard death, it is because their superiors have burdened them excessively, leaving them with no refuge. Thus, they regard death lightly. Hence the lament: "Only those who do not value life are wiser than those who cling to it."*

**Chapter 76: On the Virtue of the People’s Lifespan**
*True’s humble remark:* This chapter further expounds the principle of yielding softness to hardness, pointing to those who perish in the struggle of life and death. In my humble analysis, its profound meaning lies in the warning: *"When military might grows too strong, it cannot be sustained."*

Again, the text below states:
*"When wood is too strong, it splits; when the mighty are placed beneath, the weak rise above."* This is another stern admonition against the perils of excessive military power.

For what reason? Military force is the tool of **凶险** (harsh peril), the means of **斗争** (combat), the domain of confrontation with enemies. Thus, when military might is strong, the ruler need not fear; when the ruler fears not, the generals grow arrogant; when the generals are arrogant, the soldiers turn reckless. A ruler who does not fear, commanding arrogant generals, and generals who lord over brutalized soldiers—before they can even regroup from defeat, how could they ever triumph over their foes? Hence, the decline of the Xia and Shang dynasties saw armies of a hundred thousand perishing to overturn the Four Seas, while the end of Qin Shihuang saw his unified empire lost to the Nine Provinces. Xiang Yu rose to dominance yet fell swiftly, the Xin Dynasty seized power only to collapse immediately, Fu Jian met disaster at the Huai River, and the Tang Emperor Yang perished in the Chu Palace. These are but a few whose armies numbered in the **数兆** (myriad billions) or at least **数亿** (hundreds of millions), all relying on their strength to take victory, yet all proving the truth: *"The stronger cannot prevail."*

Again, military force seeks victory not in difficulty, but in sustaining it. Only the **道之君** (ruler of the Dao/Way) can sustain victory. The failures of these past rulers all stemmed from their inability to hold it, is it not so?

**Chapter 77: On the Dao of Heaven**
*True’s humble remark:* The analogy of the bow drawn in this chapter centers on the principle of **损益** (harmonious balance of loss and gain). It teaches that if sovereigns and lords grasp the critical balance of gain and loss, the world will naturally attain equilibrium.

*The Book of Changes* says: *"How to gather the people? By wealth."* Indeed, wealth is the proper means of governance. To restrain evil is **义** (righteousness), yet those who create wealth are the farmers and artisans, while those who deplete it are the soldiers and warriors. Since those who create wealth are few and those who destroy it are many, this is why the state endures constant deficits while hoarding surplus.

If one transforms soldiers into farmers, reducing the upper while benefiting the lower, then naturally there will be no factions or bias—just equitable application of the **大同** (Great Harmony), and thus it is said: *"Who can offer the world’s surplus to the people? Only those who follow the Dao."* This is the principle of managing wealth to aid and nurture the people.

Even though the Sage can transform the **两仪** (Two Principles—yin and yang), they do not rely on their power; though they can give birth to all things, they do not claim credit for it. They seek to let **阴德** (hidden virtue) act subtly, never boasting of their gains, hence: *"They do not desire to be seen as virtuous."* By **"见贤" (being seen as virtuous)**, it means to exalt oneself and belittle others’ goodness.

**Chapter 78: On the Softness of the World**
*True’s humble remark:* This chapter uniquely draws the analogy of water’s softness overcoming hardness. Testing this principle, we say: Even among the **五行** (Five Phases—wood, fire, earth, metal, water), earth can restrain water, yet in its extreme, earth lies within water—boring through stone, melting gold, conquering all. All rivers flow to the sea, and the Four Seas defer to Heaven. Who could say that hardness has ever prevailed over this? Hence: *"Its power cannot be replaced."* Therefore, the **道君** (ruler of the Dao/Way) deeply laments that the people of the world cannot know this marvelous principle, nor diligently practice it, hence: *"None can know it; none can act upon it."*

Again, it cites the Sage’s words: *"To bear the filth of the state, rather than its calamities,"* meaning that when the people have faults, the ruler takes them upon themselves; when the world has crimes, the ruler bears them all. The heart of a true king indeed embraces this principle, yet it seems inverted, hence: *"Right words appear as wrong."*

**Chapter 79: On Reconciling Great Grievances**
*True’s humble remark:* Heaven nurtures the people, yet great desires arise within their hearts—competing for victory, pursuing gain, turning from righteousness to wickedness. The mighty seek vengeance, the small harbor grudges. Since Heaven pities them, it establishes rulers to bring order, commanding them to reform their flaws. Yet new flaws emerge—how could this be called good? Hence: *"How can this be considered good?"*

Thus, the Sage holds the heart of **德信** (virtue and trustworthiness), practicing the teaching of **"不言之教"** (the unsaid instruction), extending grace to the **九有** (Nine Regions), and pardoning faults across the **万方** (Ten Thousands). **"契" (contract)** refers to virtue and trustworthiness; again, auspicious matters are observed on the left, and all, whether wise or foolish, are treated like cherished children, hence: *"They hold the left contract and do not blame the people."*

If a ruler does not govern the world through the Dao, but instead enforces uniformity with **刑** (punishments) and guides them with **政** (administrative measures), they cannot fully embody the **尽善之道** (principle of perfect goodness). Hence: *"Without virtue to oversee the punishments."* **"司彻" (oversee the punishments)** means to guard the traces of law and order. Again, if a ruler long persists in embodying the Dao to govern the state, then Heaven’s spirits and divine forces will always bless their reign, hence: *"The Dao of Heaven has no favorites; it always aids those of virtue."*

**Chapter 80: On Small States and Few People**
*True’s humble remark:* This chapter speaks of the ruler’s Dao—even in a great and powerful state, they must always humble themselves as small; though they possess the strength of many subjects, they must always demonstrate weakness. To humble oneself as small means to avoid the fault of pride, never losing the path of **谦柔** (humility and softness). To show weakness means to avoid the blame of over-reliance, never neglecting the preparations of defense.

Suppose there are **什人** (ten-man) leaders and **百人** (hundred-man) chiefs within the state, yet they are not employed to foster arrogance. Then the people will cherish their lives and fear death, content in their homelands and unwilling to migrate far.

Again, if **绩饷** (tribute and provisions) are not demanded, then **舟车** (boats and carriages) will have no use, and warfare ceasing means **兵甲** (arms and armor) will not be displayed. Naturally, the people will attain **太平** (Great Peace) and return to the governance of **结绳之政** (the primitive rule of knotted cords). Thus, they will find their food sweet, their clothing fine, and contentment in their hearts. Their dwellings will be secure, their customs joyful, and **风化** (cultural refinement) will flourish in the age.

For the sincere and trustworthy, there is no pursuit of flattery or boastful cleverness. They reject sweet-talking and ornate speech, eschewing cunning and embellishment. How then could they be deemed beautiful?

**Virtuous conduct and truthful speech are the **Dao/Way** of Heaven.** The Sage upholds and practices them, allowing no room for falsehood or deception to arise.

Thus, it is said: *"The **Dao/Way** of the Sage is to act without striving."*

Why then is the Sage esteemed for this principle of *"acting without striving"*? The subject believes this chapter is the final one of the **Eighty Sutras** (八十篇), and this sentence is the concluding line of the **Five Thousand Words** (五千文). Therefore, the essence of speech and the governance of affairs are fully realized here.
